scenes.title: Rituals amid uncertainty
scenes.main_point: Rituals provide structure when life feels uncertain.
scenes.scene_summary: I realized rituals mattered most when uncertainty made everything feel unsteady.
scenes.scene_prompt:
Sketched storyboard style, pencil lines, minimal shading.
One person pauses mid-morning routine, hands hovering over a simple daily ritual, realizing its importance.
In a modest home interior with a small table and everyday items; emotion: uncertain but steadied.

scenes.title: Religion to secular life
scenes.main_point: Religion historically provided structure; secularization reduced reliance on it.
scenes.scene_summary: For a long time, religion gave people structure, until secularization reduced its role.
scenes.scene_prompt:
Sketched storyboard style, pencil lines, minimal shading.
In an Enlightenment-era European town square, townspeople step away from a church doorway toward a civic building with posted notices.
A priest remains at the church entrance while a scholar gestures to the notices, suggesting a shift from religious structure to secular life.

scenes.title: Problems are inevitable
scenes.main_point: Change brings problems, and problems can be useful rather than purely bad.
scenes.scene_summary: Change brought problems, and I treated them as inevitable fuel for growth.
scenes.scene_prompt:
Sketched storyboard style, pencil lines, minimal shading.
A single person stands at a desk with scattered papers labeled “change” and “problems,” calmly sorting them into a “growth” folder.
Small office workspace; expression shows acceptance and positive engagement.

scenes.title: Morning reading ritual
scenes.main_point: A daily one-hour, phone-free reading ritual anchors the day.
scenes.scene_summary: I started each day with one focused hour of reading, with no phone nearby.
scenes.scene_prompt:
Sketched storyboard style, pencil lines, minimal shading.
One person sits at a small table, reading a Kindle or physical book for a focused hour.
Morning ritual at home; a phone is placed far away, out of reach.

scenes.title: Stoicism as balance
scenes.main_point: Stoicism is about balance, not suppressing emotions.
scenes.scene_summary: Stoic ideas aimed for balance, not emotion suppression, and felt practical in daily life.
scenes.scene_prompt:
Sketched storyboard style, pencil lines, minimal shading.
A person reads “Ego is the Enemy” by Ryan Holiday at a simple desk.
They pause, holding the book open, appearing calm and balanced as they reflect on stoicism.

scenes.title: To be vs to do
scenes.main_point: Process beats outcome-driven visualization; focus on what you do now.
scenes.scene_summary: Outcome-driven visualization missed the grind, so I focused on doing what mattered now.
scenes.scene_prompt:
Sketched storyboard style, pencil lines, minimal shading.
A person at a desk with a notebook, crossing out a thought bubble of a trophy labeled “visualization” and writing a simple to-do list labeled “daily grind.”
On the wall, a small quote card reads “To be vs to do — Derek Sivers,” showing a shift to process orientation.

scenes.title: Don’t chase passion
scenes.main_point: “Find your passion” can inflate ego; consistent work matters more.
scenes.scene_summary: Chasing passion fed ego, so I chose steady work over grand quests.
scenes.scene_prompt:
Sketched storyboard style, pencil lines, minimal shading.
A person at a simple desk with a notebook labeled “dispassionate excellence,” while a thought bubble reading “Find your passion” swells into an ego-shaped balloon.
In a quiet study, they set the balloon aside and keep writing steadily, calm and focused.
Small book spines on the desk read “Cal Newport” and “Dr Anna Lembke.”

scenes.title: Endurance sports consistency
scenes.main_point: Inspiration came from consistent action, not obsession or hype.
scenes.scene_summary: In endurance sports, I stayed unromantic about running and admired consistency over hype.
scenes.scene_prompt:
Sketched storyboard style, pencil lines, minimal shading.
A runner trains steadily on a simple track, focused and unromantic.
A small note references Kipchoge and real-life role models, emphasizing consistency over hype.

scenes.title: Earn trust through grunt work
scenes.main_point: Make teammates look good; reliability builds trust over time.
scenes.scene_summary: Early on, I took disliked tasks, delivered well, and earned trust through reliability.
scenes.scene_prompt:
Sketched storyboard style, pencil lines, minimal shading.
An intern and a small team in an office workspace; the intern takes on a stack of disliked tasks while teammates focus on their work.
Teammates glance over with growing trust as the intern delivers completed work reliably.

scenes.title: Get out of your head
scenes.main_point: Perfectionism and spotlight effect come from ego; most people aren’t watching.
scenes.scene_summary: Ego pushed perfection and spotlight fears, but most people stayed absorbed in themselves.
scenes.scene_prompt:
Sketched storyboard style, pencil lines, minimal shading.
A person stands by a wall of vision boards and a “perfect plan” checklist, looking tense.
Around them, several people in the same room stay focused on their own tasks, not watching.

scenes.title: Restraint under rejection
scenes.main_point: Feel frustration, but practice restraint; ego seeks mic-drop moments.
scenes.scene_summary: Rejections and silence hurt, but restraint kept ego from turning pain into drama.
scenes.scene_prompt:
Sketched storyboard style, pencil lines, minimal shading.
An immigrant job seeker sits at a small desk, laptop open to an interview rejection and unanswered cold emails.
They clench a fist, then relax it, holding back anger in a quiet room.

scenes.title: Infinite game and humble action
scenes.main_point: Avoid entitlement and stories; focus on controllable actions and lead with accountability.
scenes.scene_summary: I dropped entitlement and big stories, focused on daily actions, and owned outcomes as a leader.
scenes.scene_prompt:
Sketched storyboard style, pencil lines, minimal shading.
A leader at a desk reads blunt feedback notes and types a cold email, calm and accountable.
Office workspace with a simple wall note reading “No finish line,” and a small list: “Give credit / Take blame.”
